div1.head: Report: Survey of Certain Valleys on East Bank of Yadkin River, by [Henry Rose Carter], [19--]
div1.p:
Survey
of Certain Valleys
on East Bank of Yadkin River.

It is sufficient to say that many places very suitable for
breeding anopheles were found in every valley examined as it approached
the river and, in some, a long ways from it.

In general the houses of whites were farther from the river and
on higher land than those on the other side. The conformation of the
surface near the river is the same, but there is a difference in the
geological formation of the soil. I should judge that this bank, as
well as that in Anson Co. was decidedly malarious independently of any
influence of the river itself. This condition would diminish as the
land becomes higher and there would be very much less malaria in the
sandy Black Jack country of Anson and on the high peaks on both sides.
Adjacent to the river the condition was much worse below the dam than
above it, for the small distance--1 1/2 miles about--I examined. But there
were no houses seen near enough to the flats where the bad conditions
existed to be affected by them.
